questions.text: A HIV patient presented with fever and neck rigidity and a few days later the patient died even before any investigation could be performed. After autopsy the gross and histopathological image is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Cryptococcal Meningitis:

  • Hematoxylin and eosin stains show a lightly basophilic cell wall surrounded by a clear zone.
  • Cryptococcus neoformans will stain with Periodic acidSchiff or silver methenamine.
  • Mucicarmine stains the capsule-shows clear zone containing carminophilic material. Alcian blue also stains the capsule
  • Negative staining can be done by India ink stain

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Toxoplasmosis (Option B): Toxoplasma gondii causes multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the brain on imaging, particularly in HIV patients, but histology shows tachyzoites and cysts with bradyzoites, not the encapsulated budding yeasts seen here.

Herpes (Option C): Herpes simplex virus encephalitis typically involves the temporal lobes, showing hemorrhagic necrosis and perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates. It does not produce the gelatinous masses or soap-bubble lesions characteristic of cryptococcal infection.

Echinococcus multilocularis (Option D): This parasite causes multilocular hydatid cysts in the liver and, rarely, the brain. The lesions are cystic with laminated walls, not yeast-filled, gelatinous, or soap-bubble-like.

questions.text:
True about image below all except:
A. They are eosinophilic, sharply outlined bodies in nerve cells
B. These are Negri bodies seen in rabies
C. Consist of ribonuclear proteins produced by the virus
D. Consist of DNA
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Negri bodies are pathognomonic intracytoplasmic inclusions seen in rabies-infected neurons, particularly in hippocampus (pyramidal cells) and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum.
  • They are eosinophilic (pink with H&E stain), sharply outlined, round or oval cytoplasmic inclusions.
  • These inclusions are specifically called Negri bodies and are characteristic of rabies infection.
  • They consist of viral ribonucleoproteins (RNA + nucleoprotein), as rabies virus is an RNA virus.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Plexiform neurofibroma is an uncommon variant of neurofibroma, a benign tumor of peripheral nerves (WHO grade I), arising from a proliferation of all neural elements. Plexiform neurofibromas are essentially pathognomonic of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1).

NF-1:

  • Gene mutated is located on chromosome 17q
  • Characterized by cafe-au-lait spots, Lisch nodules, dysplasia of lesser wing of sphenoid and risk of developing meningioma

NF-2:

  • Due to mutation in gene located on chromosome 22q
  • Characterized by cafe-au-lait spots and bilateral vestibular schwannoma Marfan Syndrome
  • Due to a defect in the Fibrillin gene on chromosome 15.
  • Characterized by hyper flexibility of joints, subluxation of lens and cardiac problems (mitral valve prolapse, bicuspid aortic valve) Von Hippel-Lindau Syndrome
  • Gene is located on chromosome 3p
  • High risk of developing clear cell renal cell carcinoma and cerebellar hemangioblastoma, pheochromocytoma, retina hemangioblastoma.

questions.text: A patient presented with painless proptosis. Biopsy from the orbital mass showed the following image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Schwannomas often contain dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas (left) and loose, pale Antoni B areas (right), as well as hyalinized blood vessels (right). B, Antoni A area with the tumor cell nuclei aligned in palisading rows leaving anuclear zones and resulting in the formation of structures termed Verocay bodies.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Neurofibroma (Option A): This tumor is composed of Schwann cells, fibroblasts, and perineural cells, but unlike schwannoma, it is not encapsulated and tends to infiltrate the nerve. Histology shows a more disorganized pattern without Antoni A/B areas or Verocay bodies.

Rhabdomyoma (Option B): A benign tumor of striated muscle, most often found in the heart or sometimes in head and neck soft tissues. It does not arise from nerves, and histology shows large polygonal cells with cross striations rather than spindle cells in fascicles.

Leiomyoma (Option C): A benign tumor of smooth muscle, typically arising in the uterus, gastrointestinal tract, or skin. It is extremely rare in the orbit. Histology shows spindle cells with cigar-shaped nuclei rather than the Antoni pattern of schwannoma.

questions.text: A 12 your old child presented with unsteadiness of gait. A photomicrograph of an HE stained slide of the biopsy from the posterior fossa is given below. Which of the following tumours is it likely to be?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A pilocytic astrocytoma often is cystic, with a mural nodule in the wall of the cyst; if solid, it is usually well circumscribed.
  • The tumor is composed of bipolar cells with long, thin "hairlike" processes that are GFAP-positive.
  • Rosenthal fibers, eosinophilic granular bodies, and microcysts are often present, while necrosis and mitoses are rare.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Oligodendroglioma (Option A): This tumor usually arises in the cerebral hemispheres of adults, not in the posterior fossa of children. Histology shows cells with a “fried-egg” appearance (round nuclei with clear perinuclear halos) and a delicate capillary network, which is not seen here.

Diffuse astrocytoma (Option C): Typically presents in young adults, most often in the cerebral hemispheres, and shows diffusely infiltrating astrocytes without biphasic areas or Rosenthal fibers. It lacks the circumscribed growth pattern and cystic changes characteristic of pilocytic astrocytoma.

Gemistocytic astrocytoma (Option D): A variant of diffuse astrocytoma with gemistocytic (plump, eosinophilic cytoplasm) astrocytes. Again, more common in the cerebral hemispheres of adults, not in children's posterior fossa.

choices.text: Neuronal and mixed neuronal glial tumours

questions.text: Ganglioglioma is the type of glioma. In which of the following groups of CNS tumours is it included?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Gangliogliomas are tumors with a mixture of glial elements, usually a low-grade astrocytoma and mature appearing neurons.
  • Most of these tumors are slow growing, and often manifest with seizures.
  • About 20% to 50% of gangliogliomas harbor point mutations in the BRAF gene.

Explanation of Incorrect option:

Astrocytic tumours (Option A): Include pilocytic astrocytoma, diffuse astrocytoma, anaplastic astrocytoma, and glioblastoma. Ganglioglioma is not part of this group.

Ependymal tumours (Option B): Include subependymoma, myxopapillary ependymoma, and ependymoma. These arise from ependymal cells lining the ventricles. Ganglioglioma does not belong here.

Choroid plexus tumours (Option C): Include choroid plexus papilloma and carcinoma, arising from choroid plexus epithelium. Again, not related to ganglioglioma.

questions.text: Which of the following morphology is included in WHO grade II classification for meningioma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Atypical meningiomas (WHO grade II) are recognized by the presence of either an increased mitotic rate, or prominent nucleoli, increased cellularity, patternless growth, high nucleus-to cytoplasm ratio, or necrosis.
  • These tumors demonstrate more aggressive local growth and a higher rate of recurrence and may require therapy in addition to surgery.
  • Some histologic patterns-clear cell and chordoid-also correlate with more aggressive behavior, as does the presence of brain invasion.

Explanation of Incorrect option:

Meningiothelial (Option A): This is a WHO Grade I meningioma. It is the most common subtype, characterized by lobules of cells with indistinct cell borders forming whorls. It is benign and not included in WHO Grade II.

Transitional (Option B): Also a WHO Grade I meningioma. It has features of both meningothelial and fibrous types, showing whorls and fascicles. It is benign and not classified under Grade II.

Fibrous (Option D): This too belongs to WHO Grade I. It is characterized by spindle-shaped cells arranged in fascicles with abundant collagen. Benign, and not included in Grade II.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is brought to the emergency room by his parents because he is complaining about not being able to see correctly. An examination reveals bilateral temporal defects in his visual field. A CT scan of the head reveals a mass that has some calcification. Of the following, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child is presenting with bitemporal hemianopia, which is most characteristic for a tumor affecting the optic chiasm.
  • In children, the most common tumor at this site is a craniopharyngioma, which can have calcification.

CRANIOPHARYNGIOMA

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Pilocytic astrocytoma (Option A): Usually occurs in the cerebellum (posterior fossa) of children and young adults. It appears as a cystic lesion with a mural nodule but does not commonly cause visual field defects or calcification in the suprasellar region.

Medulloblastoma (Option B): A malignant small round blue cell tumor typically found in the cerebellum of children. Presents with ataxia, headache, and hydrocephalus due to obstruction of CSF flow - not with bitemporal hemianopia.

Ependymoma (Option C): Arises in the ventricular system (commonly 4th ventricle in children), leading to hydrocephalus from CSF obstruction. Again, it does not classically involve the optic chiasm or produce calcifications in the suprasellar region.

choices.text: It is likely to metastasize to the liver

questions.text: A 13-year-old child is brought to the emergency room by EMTs because he had a seizure during breakfast, which was witnessed and reported by his parents. A CT scan of the head reveals a mass in the left cerebral hemisphere, which is subsequently excised by a neurosurgeon. A pathologist identifies numerous Rosenthal fibers and notes that the tumor is GFAP positive. Of the following, what is another feature of this tumor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Microscopically, low-grade (WHO grade II) astrocytomas are characterized by a mild to moderate increase in the number of glial cell nuclei, somewhat variable nuclear pleomorphism, and an intervening feltwork of fine, glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)-positive astrocytic cell processes that give the background a fibrillary appearance.
  • The transition between neoplastic and normal tissue is indistinct, and tumor cells can be seen infiltrating normal tissue many centimeters from the main lesion.

PILOCYTIC ASTROCYTOMA.

  • Oval To Irregular Tumor Nuclei Resembling Those Of Diffuse Astrocytoma, But With Numerous Rosenthal Fibers In Back Ground

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Poor prognosis (Option A): Incorrect — Pilocytic astrocytoma is a WHO Grade I tumor with an excellent prognosis, particularly after surgical resection. Poor prognosis is more characteristic of high-grade astrocytomas such as glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV), not pilocytic astrocytoma.

Commonly produces erythropoietin (Option B): Incorrect — Erythropoietin production is typical of hemangioblastomas, especially in the cerebellum and in association with von Hippel–Lindau disease. Pilocytic astrocytomas do not secrete erythropoietin.

Likely to metastasize to the liver (Option C): Incorrect — Primary CNS tumors, including pilocytic astrocytomas, almost never metastasize outside the CNS because of the blood–brain barrier and absence of lymphatics. They are locally confined and do not spread to systemic organs like the liver.

choices.text: The tumor most frequently occurs at the cerebellopontine angle
The tumor derives from Rathke's pouch
The appearance of the tumor cells is sometimes described as a fried egg

questions.text: A pathologist is examining a brain tumor resected from a 63-year-old male. The pathologist identifies psammoma bodies in the histologic section. Of the following, what is true of this tumor type?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among brain tumors, psammoma bodies are most frequently associated with meningiomas.
  • Meningiomas are a common type of brain tumor.
  • They occur at parasagittal regions.(Option B ruled out)
  • They are derived from arachnoidal cells.(Option C ruled out)
  • Oligodendrogliomas have a fried egg appearance.(Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which amongst the following is a highly vascular neoplasm that occurs as a mural nodule associated with a large, fluid-filled cyst?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hemangioblastoma, the principal neurologic manifestation of the disease, is a highly vascular neoplasm that occurs as a mural nodule associated with a large, fluid-filled cyst.
  • These occur most commonly in the cerebellum, but can be found along the spinal cord and in the retina, and rarely at other sites in the brain.
  • On microscopic examination, the lesion consists of numerous capillary-sized or somewhat larger thin-walled vessels separated by intervening stromal cells with a vacuolated, lightly PAS-positive, lipid-rich cytoplasm.
  • These stromal cells express inhibin, a member of the TGF-β family, which serves as a useful diagnostic marker.

Craniopharyngioma (Option A): Craniopharyngiomas arise from Rathke's pouch remnants and usually occur in the suprasellar region. They are often calcified, cystic tumors that cause visual field defects (bitemporal hemianopia), but they are not highly vascular mural nodules.

Medulloblastoma (Option B): Medulloblastomas are malignant small round blue cell tumors usually located in the cerebellum of children. They are solid, highly cellular tumors that can cause obstructive hydrocephalus. They do not present as vascular mural nodules with cysts.

Meningioma (Option D): Meningiomas arise from arachnoid cap cells and are usually dural-based solid tumors. They are not typically cystic, nor do they form mural nodules. Psammoma bodies are a classic feature, not vascular mural nodules.

questions.text: Which is the most common brain tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most common brain tumour is Metastatic tumour and the most common primary brain tumour is meningioma.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Meningioma (Option A): Meningiomas are the most common primary benign brain tumor, arising from arachnoid cap cells. However, they are not the most common brain tumors overall - metastases outnumber them.

Glioma (Option C): Gliomas (a broad category including astrocytomas, oligodendrogliomas, and glioblastomas) are the most common primary malignant brain tumors in adults. But again, when considering all brain tumors (primary and secondary), metastases are more frequent.

Medulloblastoma (Option D): Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children, typically arising in the cerebellum. However, it is not the most common brain tumor overall.

questions.text: Which is the most common metastatic tumour to the brain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Metastatic lesions, mostly carcinomas, account for approximately one-fourth to one-half of intracranial tumors.
  • The most common primary sites are lung, breast, skin (melanoma), kidney, and gastrointestinal tract, which together account for about 80% of cases.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Gastrointestinal stromal tumour (Option B): GISTs usually metastasize to the liver and peritoneum, not to the brain. Brain metastases from GIST are extremely rare.

Ovarian germ cell tumour (Option C): Ovarian tumors typically metastasize within the peritoneal cavity(peritoneal spread, omental caking). Brain metastasis is uncommon.

Breast carcinoma (Option D): Breast cancer is indeed a very common cause of brain metastases, second only to lung cancer. However, lung (especially small cell carcinoma) is still the most common single source overall.

questions.text: Which is the most common malignant tumour of the brain (primary) in the pediatric population?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant primary brain tumor in children.It arises from the cerebellum (vermis) and is a primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET).Commonly seen in children aged 3-8 years.
  • Highly cellular, composed of small round blue cells, often showing Homer Wright rosettes.
  • Spreads via CSF pathways (drop metastases).
  • Clinical features include:Ataxia, nystagmus, headache, and signs of raised intracranial pressure.

Explanation of other options:

  • Juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma(Option A):Most Common primary benign brain tumour in pediatric
  • Meningioma(option C):Most Common primary benign brain tumour in adult .
  • Glioblastoma(Option D):Most Common primary malignant brain tumour in adults.

MEDULLOBLASTOMA

questions.text: What is the most common site for Juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pilocytic astrocytomas are relatively benign tumors that typically affect children and young adults.
  • Most commonly located in the cerebellum, they also may involve the third ventricle, the optic pathways, the spinal cord, and occasionally the cerebral hemispheres.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Brain stem (Option B): Incorrect - Brainstem gliomas do occur in children but are usually diffuse intrinsic pontine gliomas (DIPG), which have a poor prognosis. JPAs are more commonly cerebellar rather than brainstem.

Sellar region (Option C): Incorrect - A sellar/suprasellar mass in children is more often a craniopharyngioma or sometimes a hypothalamic astrocytoma. While pilocytic astrocytomas can occur here, it is not the most common site.

Cerebrum (Option D): Incorrect - Low-grade gliomas can occur in the cerebral hemispheres, but in children, JPAs are most frequently found in the posterior fossa (cerebellum), not in the cerebrum.

questions.text: What is the characteristic feature of Oligodendroglioma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnostic features of Oligodendroglioma are:

  • Anastomosing capillaries
  • fried egg tumour cells (Perinuclear halo surrounding the nucleus)
  • Perineuronal satellitosis
  • Oligodendroglioma. Tumor nuclei are round, with cleared cytoplasm forming halos and vasculature composed of thin - walled capillaries.

Explanation of other options:

  • Rosenthal fibres(Option A): It is seen in Pilocytic astrocytoma.These are eosinophilic, corkscrew-shaped fibers in astrocytic processes.
  • Palisading necrosis(Option B):Characteristics of Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM).Refers to tumor cells lined up around areas of necrosis.Absent in oligodendrogliomas.
  • Butterfly shape margins(Option D):It is seen in Glioblastoma, due to spread across the corpus callosum.Gives a butterfly appearance on imaging.

choices.text: SHH activated with wild type tp53

questions.text: Which amongst the following is NOT included in the WHO classification of medulloblastoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

WHO Classification of medulloblastoma:

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

WNT type (Option A): WNT-activated medulloblastomas form one distinct molecular group. They typically have a good prognosis.

SHH activated with mutant TP53 (Option B): This is a recognized subgroup. SHH-activated, TP53-mutant tumors usually occur in older children/adolescents and tend to have a worse prognosis.

SHH activated with wild type TP53 (Option C): Another valid subgroup. These usually occur in infants and younger children, with variable prognosis depending on other features.

choices.text: Only i, ii, and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following is true
i) About 70% of childhood CNS tumours arise in the posterior fossa.
ii) About 10% of childhood CNS tumours arise in the posterior fossa.
iii) 70% of adult CNS tumours arise within the cerebral hemispheres above the tentorium.
iv) 25% of adult CNS tumours arise within the cerebral hemispheres above the tentorium.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Childhood CNS tumors differ from those in adults in both histologic subtype and location. In childhood, tumors are likely to arise in the posterior fossa(70%), whereas tumors in adults are mostly supratentorial.
  • More than half of all CNS tumours in children are found in the posterior cranial fossa or in the brain stem. A tumour in this region may obstruct CSF drainage and thus increase the intracranial pressure.

choices.text: Increased polymorphs, normal sugar and high protein
Increased mononuclear cells, low sugar and low protein
Increased Polymorphs, low sugar, high protein
Increased lymphocytes, normal sugar, high protein

questions.text: A 17 years old female is presented with a history of fever and headache and now she develops altered sensorium. CT scan shows basal exudates with meningeal enhancement. CSF culture showed isolation of gram positive bacilli. In CSF examination, which of the following laboratory findings are seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CSF Findings in Bacterial Meningitis:

  • Increased Polymorphs:Bacterial meningitis typically shows a high number of polymorphonuclear cells (polymorphs) in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). These cells indicate an acute inflammatory response.
  • Low Sugar (Glucose) Levels:Bacterial meningitis results in decreased CSF glucose levels. The bacteria consume glucose in the CSF as a nutrient source.
  • High Protein Levels:In bacterial meningitis, the permeability of meningeal blood vessels increases due to inflammation. This leads to elevated protein levels in the CSF.

Pathological Changes in Acute Meningitis:

  • Leptomeningeal Exudate:In acute meningitis, there's an exudate within the leptomeninges on the brain's surface. Leptomeninges refer to the delicate innermost layer of the meninges.
  • Prominent Meningeal Vessels:The blood vessels within the meninges become engorged and prominent due to inflammation.
  • Pus Formation:In severe cases, tracts of pus can extend along blood vessels in the meninges.

Microscopic Examination:

  • Neutrophil Presence:Neutrophils, a type of white blood cell, are the predominant cell type in the CSF in bacterial meningitis. They may fill the entire subarachnoid space or concentrate around meningeal blood vessels.
  • Gram Staining:In untreated meningitis, Gram staining may reveal the causative organism.

Complications:

  • Venous Involvement:Severe inflammation may lead to phlebitis, affecting leptomeningeal veins. This can result in venous occlusion and hemorrhagic infarction of the brain tissue.
  • Brain Abscess Formation:In some cases, the infection and inflammatory cells can spread into the brain tissue, leading to focal cerebritis and the formation of abscesses.
  • Ventricular Involvement:Extension of the infection into the brain's ventricles (ventriculitis) can also occur.

Treatment Outcome:

  • Effective Treatment:Early and effective treatment can resolve meningitis with little to no residual effects.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Increased polymorphs, normal sugar and high protein (Option A):

This is not correct because in bacterial meningitis, CSF sugar is typically low, not normal. Normal glucose would more likely point to a viral meningitis picture, not acute bacterial.

Increased mononuclear cells, low sugar and low protein (Option B):

This is incorrect because although mononuclear cells with low sugar suggest TB or fungal meningitis, the protein is never low — it is usually elevated.

Increased lymphocytes, normal sugar, high protein (Option D):

This is incorrect because this CSF profile corresponds to viral meningitis, where lymphocytic predominance, normal glucose, and mildly elevated protein are seen — not the case in this patient with bacterial meningitis.

questions.text: Which organism causes Cerebral malaria?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Plasmodium falciparum is the only species of malaria parasite that causes cerebral malaria, a life-threatening complication.
  • It leads to:
    • Sequestration of infected RBCs in cerebral microvasculature.
    • Vascular blockage, hypoxia, hemorrhages, and brain edema.
    • Presents with altered sensorium, seizures, coma, and high mortality.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Plasmodium vivax (Option B): Incorrect - P. vivax typically causes benign tertian malaria with less severe complications. It rarely leads to cerebral involvement or severe malaria.

Toxoplasma gondii (Option C): Incorrect - T. gondii causes toxoplasmosis, which can produce brain lesions in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV/AIDS) but is not a cause of cerebral malaria.

Taenia solium (Option D): Incorrect - T. solium causes neurocysticercosis, leading to seizures and cystic brain lesions, but it is not related to malaria.

questions.text: The triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications are seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cerebral infection with the protozoan Toxoplasma gondii can occur in immunosuppressed adults or in newborns who acquire the organism transplacentally from a mother with an active infection.
  • The consequences include the triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications.
  • In adults, the clinical symptoms are subacute, evolving over weeks, and may be both focal and diffuse.
  • Due to inflammation and breakdown of the blood-brain barrier at sites of infection, imaging studies often show edema associated with ring-enhancing lesions.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Candida albicans (Option A): Incorrect - Candida can cause CNS infections like meningitis or abscesses, especially in immunocompromised patients, but it does not produce the classic triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications.

Mucormycosis (Option B): Incorrect - Mucormycosis primarily affects sinuses, orbit, and brain in immunocompromised patients, often leading to necrotizing infections, but it does not cause congenital-type CNS findings like the triad.

Cysticercosis (Option D): Incorrect - Neurocysticercosis leads to cystic lesions, seizures, and calcifications, but chorioretinitis and congenital hydrocephalus are not characteristic. The full triad is specific to congenital toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: Which cells of the brain are affected by polyoma virus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is caused by JC virus, a polyomavirus, which preferentially infects oligodendrocytes, resulting in demyelination as these cells are injured and then die.
  • Most people show serologic evidence of exposure to JC virus during childhood, and it is believed that PML results from virus reactivation, as the disease is restricted to immunosuppressed individuals.
  • Patients develop focal and relentlessly progressive neurologic signs and symptoms, and imaging studies show extensive, often multifocal lesions in the hemispheric or cerebellar white matter.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Astrocytes (Option B): While astrocytes may show reactive changes in viral infections, the primary target of polyomavirus (JC virus) is oligodendrocytes, not astrocytes. Astrocytic changes are secondary.

Microglia (Option C): Microglia are the CNS resident macrophages and may become activated during infection, but they are not directly infected by polyomavirus.

Ependymal cells (Option D): Ependymal cells line the ventricles and can be involved in inflammation, but they are not the primary site of JC virus infection. The hallmark of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is oligodendrocyte infection leading to demyelination.

questions.text: Which CNS infection causes lesions in temporal lobes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • HSV-1 encephalitis may occur in any age group but is most common in children and young adults.
  • It typically manifests with alterations in mood, memory, and behavior, reflecting involvement of the frontal and temporal lobes.
  • Recurrent HSV-1 encephalitis is sometimes associated with inherited mutations that interfere with Toll-like receptor signaling (specifically that of TLR-3), which has an important role in anti-viral defense.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

C. Neoformans (Option A): Incorrect - Cryptococcus primarily affects meninges, causing cryptococcal meningitis, especially in immunocompromised patients. It does not selectively involve the temporal lobes.

N. meningitidis (Option B): Incorrect - Neisseria meningitidis causes acute bacterial meningitis, affecting the leptomeninges diffusely, not the temporal lobes specifically.

CMV (Option D): Incorrect - Cytomegalovirus CNS infection is typically seen in immunocompromised patients and produces periventricular lesions or ventriculitis, rather than selective temporal lobe involvement.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman suddenly lost consciousness and upon awakening 1 hour later, she could not speak or move her right arm. Two months later, a head CT scan showed a large tumor in the left frontal lobe with serpentine necrosis with pseudopalisading. Which of the following tumors has most likely occurred in her brain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario,the frontal lobe lesion explains speech disturbance (Broca's aphasia) and contralateral hemiparesis (right arm weakness) with acute onset followed by persistent neurological deficits also fits the highly aggressive nature of glioblastoma.
  • Glioblastoma is described as the most malignant astrocytic tumor (WHO grade IV).
  • Key features include:
    • Pseudopalisading necrosis: tumor cells crowding around areas of necrosis in a serpentine or geographic pattern.
    • Microvascular proliferation is another diagnostic hallmark.
  • Clinical features: Rapidly progressive neurologic symptoms occurring predominantly in older adults, commonly in cerebral hemispheres, particularly frontal and temporal lobes.

Explanation of other options:

  • Meningioma(Option B):It is usually benign and extra-axial (arising from meninges).Often well-circumscribed, may cause slowly progressive symptoms due to compression.
  • Medulloblastoma(Option C):It is common in children, rarely seen in elderly.Arises in the cerebellum, leading to ataxia, not speech/language deficits or hemiparesis.Histology shows small round blue cells, Homer Wright rosettes, not pseudopalisading necrosis.
  • Oligodendroglioma(Option D):It occurs in younger adults, commonly in frontal lobes.Characterized by fried-egg appearance, chicken-wire vasculature, and calcifications.
